hedline.hl1: AT&T Shares Up on Speedy At Home Deal

body.head.byline: By SIMON ROMERO with ANTHONY DePALMA

abstract.p: AT&T's stock rises on news that company has incorporated ExciteAtHome into its operations more quickly than expected, suggesting a faster move to high-speed Internet services; Standard & Poor's puts company's debt on review for a possible downgrade, citing management miscues and costly acquisitions; AT&T Latin America merges with FirstCom, a South American telecommunications company, to form a specialized broadband communications provider (M)

block.p: AT&T's stock rose yesterday on the news that the company had incorporated Excite@Home into its operations more quickly than expected, suggesting a speedier move into high-speed Internet services.

But it was not all good news for AT&T investors. Standard & Poor's said yesterday that it had put the company's debt on review for a possible downgrade, citing management miscues and costly acquisitions.
AT&T's stock rose yesterday on the news that the company had incorporated Excite@Home into its operations more quickly than expected, suggesting a speedier move into high-speed Internet services.

But it was not all good news for AT&T investors. Standard & Poor's said yesterday that it had put the company's debt on review for a possible downgrade, citing management miscues and costly acquisitions.

After the stock markets closed on Monday, AT&T said that it had increased its voting stake in Excite@Home to 74 percent from 56 percent, giving it a controlling interest. AT&T will now include in its own results the figures for Excite@Home, a broadband provider based in Redwood City, Calif. The companies had been expected to consolidate their financial results in the fourth quarter.

''AT&T has thrown a life preserver to Excite,'' said Emily Meehan, an analyst at the Yankee Group, a communications consulting company. ''Now it remains to be seen whether Excite will bleed profits from AT&T or get turned around.''

Investors bid AT&T's stock up $1.13, to $32 yesterday, but the shares remain deeply depressed, off nearly 50 percent from the 52-week high in November. The company is said to be considering a number of ways to bolster the stock.

S.& P., the credit-rating agency, cited concerns about AT&T's costly acquisitions of TCI and MediaOne, which made it the nation's largest cable television operator, as major reasons for putting the stock on its watch list for possible downgrade.

''This isn't a fait accompli, but it shows we're very concerned about the general direction of AT&T,'' said Rick Siderman, senior telecommunications credit analyst at Standard & Poor's. Still, it is not clear if any downgrade will increase AT&T's borrowing costs, because Moody's Investors Service already rates AT&T lower than S.& P.
S.& P. said that AT&T's long-term debt could be cut more than one notch below its double-A- rating and its short-term rating of A-1+.

In addition, S.& P. expressed concerns about ''operational and management miscues'' in AT&T's core businesses of long-distance service, which has been squeezed by fierce competition, and its wireless services -- concerns echoed by others.
''Management has gone from little room for error to almost none,'' said Pascal Aguirre, principal in the business strategy group at Renaissance Strategy Worldwide.

Closing the Excite@Home transaction early will have little impact on the company's earnings projections for the entire year, stock analysts said. But for the third quarter, AT&T's earnings will be reduced by an estimated 5 cents. Operating earnings will be 35 to 38 cents a share, the company said, down from its previous target of 40 cents to 43 cents a share.
Excite@Home lost an estimated $2.5 billion last year on revenue of about $500 million and continues to lose money this year, according to Renaissance Strategy.

AT&T picked up another company yesterday that did little to improve its bottom line immediately but gave it a solid footing in Latin America. AT&T Latin America, which was formed by AT&T last year, merged with the South American telecommunications company FirstCom to form Latin America's newest specialized broadband communications provider.

FirstCom, whose stock had been traded on the Nasdaq, has served businesses and other high-volume customers in major cities in Chile, Colombia and Peru. During the first six months of this year, it posted a net loss of $32.4 million, or $1.06 a share. Patricio Northland, FirstCom's chief executive, attributed the losses to the heavy build-out of the company's fiber optics network in the three countries.

The new AT&T Latin America stock began trading on Nasdaq yesterday and closed virtually unchanged at $17.38. Since the regional company was formed last year, AT&T Latin America has aggressively moved into the region, by acquiring Netstream in Brazil and Keytech LD in Argentina.

Mr. Northland, who is now chief executive of AT&T Latin America, said the company had identified 22 business centers in Latin America where it would focus its marketing efforts. It already has a substantial presence in 10 of them.
